DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Calls for Improved Relations with Argentina
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher called Friday for improved commercial and diplomatic relations with Argentina, but she also insisted Britain retain control of the disputed Falkland Islands. In a Christmas address to the 1,800 islanders, Mrs. Thatcher said Britain, in recent talks with the new Argentine government, had not wavered from its position that control of the South Atlantic islands is not negotiable. In the speech broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corp., Mrs. Thatcher said Britain would uphold its commitments to residents of the Falklands. Argentine troops invaded the British colony off southern Argentina in 1982. Britain sent troops and drove out the invaders in a 74-day war. Diplomatic relations between the two countries were broken. Argentina has claimed sovereignty to the islands it calls the Malvinas since 1832. On Argentina, Mrs. Thatcher said: ``We want to improve ordinary commercial and diplomatic relations because that is in the interests of us all, including the Falkland Islands.''
